HOPKINS TOO MUCH FOR STEVENS

TEAMS FOR TRIANGULAR DEBATE

HOPKINS WINS PRACTICE MEET

GROTIUS SOCIETY LOSE DEBATE

The Lacrosse Team Covers Itself With
Glory and Mud at Homewood
on Saturday Afternoon.

Arrangements for Contest Are About
Complete and the Event Should
Prove Very Interesting.

Lloyd's Work Exceptional—Lee Makes
Initial Appearance in Mile Run
and Wins—Spring Schedule.

Zelosophic Society of U. of P. Get the
Decision Over Varsity Debaters—A
Supper Tendered Visitors.

The lacrosse team had very little
difficAty in splashing its way to a
victory over Stevens last Saturday.
When the final whistle blew, the
score stood i T to 0, and that with
five men in the line-up who had not
played this season. The field was
soggy and very slippery after two
days' rain, which did not let up
during the game, but their cleated
shoes held the players up well.
At the break, Beatty drove the
ball to Tappan and a rush was made
for the Stevens' goal; but on Bassett
recovering a wild pass, drove the
ball up the field again. Several minutes later Troxell, receiving a pass
from Hulburt, shot for the first
tally. For the rest of the half the
ball was almost always before the
Stevens' net, the mid-fielders following it hard and driving it back as
often as it came up.

Final arrangements for the triangular debate to be held next Friday night between Hopkins, Virginia, and North Carolina, are under
way at all three colleges. Teams
have all been selected and are now
hard at work putting the finishing
touches on their speeches.
The debate in McCoy Hall will
be between Virginia and North
Carolina, Carolina supporting the
negative and Virginia the affirmative
of the question:
"Resolved, That disregarding the
Hav-Pauncefote treaty, the tolls of
the Panama Canal should be the
same for merchant ships of all nations.The Virginia team will consist of
Messrs. Adams and Bozman, speakers. and Via, alternate. North Carolina will be represented by W. F.
Taylor, of the Law School, and
J. C. Busby, of the senior class.

The triangular meet between the
University, the Central Y. M. C. A.,
and the Cross Country Club was
easily taken by the Hopkins team
on Friday. The 220-yard dash was
the only event not won by a 'Varsity
man. Brockman, of the Y. M. C. A.,
won it from Wagner. In eight
events Hopkins won all three places.
It was good to see Lee out again
in the mile run. He won in 4 minutes 443A seconds, remarkable time
for this part of the season and the
water-soaked track. Rain fell all
through the meet. Lloyd won the
Too-yard dash in ToY5 seconds, and
captured the 440 later, in 53/5 seconds, after starting six yards behind
the mark, due to two false starts.
Groover vas close to him at the finish..
The field events were dangerous,
on account of the wet take-off. Dig-

The Grotius Society of Hopkins
was defeated Friday night in their
debate with the Zelosophic Society
of the University of Pennsylvania.
The decision of the judges was two
to one against the Grotius representatives. The orators for the Hopkins' Society were George Rusk,
chairman; David N. Shulman, and
T. J. Tingley. Nachlas was alternate and Gminder advisor. The
Pennsylvanias were: Bell, Pinola,
Brosius, Ripple and Hager. The
subject for debate was compulsory
arbitration for industrial disputes,
the affirmative of which was supported by the Grotius Society.
Before a small but interested audience, Dr. French, who was the
presiding officer, introduced Shulman, Kuehn and Gminder, a trio
that put much life into those present by their rendering of Mozart's
first movement. Tingley was the'

Woman's Civic League.

On Monday, April 7, the Woman's Civic League held a meeting in
McCoy Hall, which was addressed
by Ezra B. Whitman, president of
Baltimore's Water Board. His subject was "The Water Supply of Baltimore." He illustrated, by means of
stereopticon views, how the water
BALTIMORE, MD.
is drawn from the reservoirs on
the Gunpowder River, at Loch
Raven, into the city. He told that
the water system of Baltimore
would soon be practically perfect,
and that there will be no possibility
SUMMER COURSES
in the future of drouths of any duration.
On Friday, April 18, the League
July 1 —August 12

1913
Manhattan Trade School, on the

Gorter, Health Commissioner of Baltimore, will speak before the League
on the subject: "Safeguarding the

students and undergraduates, constituting a social unit. .. Each hall

of each of the several classes of occupants. A dining-room should be

It is needless for us to try to point
out the excellent features of these
plans. The quotations from Dean
Griffin's article are enough, of themselves, to give promise of a happy
life at Homewood. We can only
regret that we, as undergraduates,
will be unable to experience that
life.
Lateness.

Homewood Again.

Some modern sages have remarked that men get more enjoyment in looking forward to a certain
event or pleasure than they do in
the experiencing of the event or
pleasure itself. Whether this is true
or not, we who are to be denied the
enjoyment of the life at Homewood
may yet derive some small amount
of pleasure from looking forward
to the time when the University will
change its quarters, and in talking
of the many fine things that it is
going to- have when it gets there.
One of the advantages that we may
hope to secure when Homewood becomes a reality is the greater facility
afforded for social life among the
students themselves. When the
Johns Hopkins will have its campus
and quadrangle, its dormitories and
frat houses, all grouped together
at. Homewood in "the delightful seclusion of this historic estate, with
its 120 acres of lawn and shade,"
the undergraduate life ought to become broader and mean more to the
student than it can now amid -the
prosaic sights and the disturbing
sounds of city streets." It should,
therefore, be of interest to us all to
learn of the plans that are being
made, for the social side of college
life at Homewood.
In the March issue of the Alumni
Magazine appears an article on "The
College in the University" by Dean
E. H. Griffin, of the college faculty.
Plans for residence at Homewood
are there outlined. The halls Of
residence that may be erected at
Homewood will not be like the traditional college dormitory, with "its
commonplace architecture and the
rough and ready manner of its occupants." Our halls are to be "dignified additions to the group of collegiate buildings, and those who occupy them will observe the same
rules of decorum that would be ob-

"For verily, I say unto you, the
first shall be last, and the last shall
be first."
If we were sure that this were
the motto of many of the undergraduate students in the University,
we would be tempted to believe that
a part, yea, a very large part, of the
students were out trying for the
Rhodes scholarships, Phi Beta
Kappa keys, prizes, honors, etc.
But since our common sense tells
us that no very large part of the
students are trying to become shining stars in the scholarship world,
we must seek some other explanation of the state of affairs that has
led us to believe that perhaps some
of the students had selected the
above quotation as their motto.
The reason why we are brought
to this conclusion must be of itself
apparent to all who attend undergraduate classes. There is hardly
a class from Monday morning until
Friday afternoon where every one
is in his seat, or even in the room,
when the hour bell rings. When
we try to explain this deplorable
condition, we are at a loss to find
adequate -quid propter" s. Of course
when we go to the theatre or to
the cotillon or to a reception, etc.,
it is understood that it would be
highly improper for us to be on
time. But why should this custom
be brought into class? When you
come tripping in, five, ten, or fifteen
minutes after the hour, no one is
benefited by the fact, every one is
disturbed, and you have lost part of.
the lecture or recitation. And the
worst thing about this custom of
being late is the fact that it is largely
due to carelessness and indifference.
You must finish your cigarette.
stump, get the mail from your box,
finish your conversation, tell another
stale joke, or wait for the next uncertain trip of the elevator.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
A Shower of Stones.

.

APRIL 14, 1913.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—At the Cotillon Board,
which has undoubtedly been alive
and has improved the cotillons remarkably this year, it may seem ungrateful to throw stones. Before
"casting the first stone," let me mention what the Board has done toward improving the dances: First,
there is a regular receiving committee. As is very proper, all the girls
and men before entering the roOm
are introduced to several of the
chaperons who are on the committee. Much better and more dignified, is it not, than the former practice of never speaking to the chaperons? Second, the music has been
notably bettered. While it seemed
a shame to get rid of the old man
who has played so long and so faithfully at the University functions,
we cannot always sacrifice ourselves
to sentiment. With "Lewie" Fisher
or one of his right hand men,
"ginger" has come into the dances
in a truly remarkable way. Third,
the number of men coming to the
dance has been greatly increased.
The cotillon is now truly a Univer-

sity affair. And if the members of
the Board were present at this writing they could undoubtedly suggest
a fourth or fifth improvement which
has been made, but were I to mention them here I should have no
room to "sling my stones."
Stone No. L—Although the orchestra had finished the first eight
dances by ten or quarter past, the
second half of the dances did not
commence until eleven o'clock. Why
on Saturday night, when we can
only dance until twelve, this lengthy
hour for refreshments. The writer
does not complain. For him the
time passed only too rapidly. He
is slinging in behalf of the stags and
the men who "didn't bring fairies."
The cause for this long intermission
has been given as the poor arrangements for supper. If so, let the arrangements be bettered.
Stone No. 2—Perhaps it was because the noted "Lewie" was performing at the Country Club, and a
substitute was on the job, that one
had to clap like the deuce before getting an encore. And perhaps the
fact that the substitute tired easily
was the reason for the long waits
between dances. To some these
long intermissions might not have
been disagreeable maybe the other
fellows liked to talk more ,than
dance—in striking juxtaposition to
myself.

Time is fleeting—
and in that respect it's
just like money.
But it doesn't require much time—nor
money either—to get
a big red tin of

Scientific Association.

The Johns Hopkins Scientific Association met last Tuesday, April 8,
in the physical laboratory. The meeting was addressed by Mr. John A.
Brashear, on the subject of "Recent
Studies in the Domain of Astrophysics." Mr. Bra.shear has done
much work lately in connection with
the physics of the heavenly bodies,
and his lecture dealt with the results
of his experiments. On Thursday,
April 3, the Association held a subscription dinner in the Johns Hopkins Club. The dinner was followed by a talk on "Recent Work
With Regard to the Constitution of
Matt," by Prof. J. S. Ames. This
lecture was in the nature of a resume of those Professor Ames delivered on his recent trip to the
Northwestern University.

Hopkins and Navy, Evenly Matched,
Put Up a Great Struggle for
Supremacy at Annapolis.

At Annapolis last Thursday 'afternoon, after 65 minutes of the most
Stubborn fighting, the lacrosse game
with the Navy ended with the score
a tie-4 to 4. The two teams could
not have been more evenly matched,
and at no time during the game was
either the Black and Blue or the
Blue and Gold more than one point
ahead.
The rival captains agreed upon
25 and 20 minutes as the time of
the halves, but at the close of these
periods the score stood a tie at 3
to 3. Then it was agreed to play
an extra period of m minutes.
Mainly through the splendid work
of the two goal tenders, neither
team was able to score during this
time. Then a second period of the
same length was agreed upon, at
the end. of which, whatever the
score, the game was to stop. During this time both teams tallied once.
Hopkins drew first blood, when
after about three minutes of play,
Captain Johnny Huck made one of
his famous drives. The advantage
did not last long, however, for,
within a few moments Gray slipped
the ball passed Sears for the Navy's
first count. After twelve more minutes of splendid playing on the part
of both teams, Tappan scored the
second point for the Black and Blue.
Again Navy evened up, Gray caging
the ball for his second goal, and the
half ended with the score 2 to 2.
The Middies began the second
period at a fast clip, and in less than
two minutes Davis succeeded in getting a hard drive into the net. It
was not long, however, before Hollyday succeeded in making a shot
from a mix-up in front of the Navy
goal. There was no more scoring
during this half.
During the first of the extra periods each side had several chances
to score, but both .showed stalwart
defense. After about seven minutes
of the second extra stanza, Navy
gained the lead when Mitchell made
a count. With only three minutes
remaining, Hopkins, showing brilliant ability to come back, took a
wonderful brace, and immediately
evened up the score. The tally was
made by LaMotte, who received a
pass from behind the Middies' goal.
The balance of the time was full
of spirited playing, although both
teams showed the result-of the fast
pace.
Aside from the splendid work of
the two goal tenders, which was
easily the featuresof the game, Huck,
Hollyday, Tappan, and the close attack starred for Hopkins, while
Mitchell, Starkey, Gray and. Davis
played brilliantly for the Navy.

Dr. Paul Eugene Bleuler, professor of psychiatry in the University
of Zurich, Switzerland, who is to
be one of the distinguished guests
at the opening of the new Phipps
Clinic, has already reached Baltimore. He arrived in the city last
Wednesday and will be entertained
during his stay by Dr. Adolf
Meyer, professor of psychiatry in
the Medical School, at his home,
1012 North Calvert street.
Dr. Meyer received a degree of
doctor of laws from the University
of Zurich in 1892.
Sir William Osler, hohorary professor of medicine, now regius professor of medicine at Oxford, will
arrive here on April 15.
The opening of the Phipps Clinic
will take place on April 16, and the
exercises will continue during the
17th and 18th, an elaborate program having been arranged.
The formal opening has been set
for 3 P. M. on the 16th, on which
occasion addresses will be'made by
Dr. Welch, Dr. Stewart Paton,
Judge Harlan and Sir William
Osier. The program for the remaining days is as follows:

Harvard Game on Tuesday.

The baseball game between Harvard and Johns Hopkins which was
to have been the feature of last Saturday's doubleheader, and which
could not be played on account of
rain, will be played tomorrow afternoon at Homewood. The arrangement in regard to the .game for
Tuesday was reached by Manager
F. W. Hubbell of Harvatd and
Manager C. Leland .Getz of the
Johns Hopkins team last Saturday
night. Both teams are very anxious
for the game to be played. If the
weather is good a very large crowd
should turn out for the game, as
Harvard always proves a big drawing card in Baltimore.
Although prevented by the rainy
weather of the past few days from
having a practice since the Princeton game, the Black and Blue nine
is in very good shape. Steady progress has been made since the opening of the season, and the good
showing made against Princeton
last Wednesday is an evidence of
what the Hopkins team is capable
of. With Sutton and Porter back
in the line-up the prospects of
defeating Harvard are especially
bright. All those who are contemplating being present may look forward to a mighty good exhibition of
college baseball. The gam" is
scheduled to start at four o'clock.

HOPKINS WINS PACTICE MEET

(Continued from page I.)

(Continuedfrom page 1.)

The debate should be most interesting for two reasons: First, the
ancient rivalry of . Virginia and
Carolina in the debating field, and
second, the importance of the subject which will be discussed.
Virginia and Carolina have met
four times in debates and each has
the honor of two victories. Each
will, therefore, be fighting for the
"rubber" next Friday night, and
what this means will be realized
when it is considered that out of
thirty-four intercollegiate debates
since 1897, North Carolina has won
twenty-four, and that she considers
Virginia her most important rival.
The Panama tolls seem to be the
most popular debating subject of
the season. They were the subject
of the Harvard-Yale-Princeton triangular debate on March 14. Several weeks later the Barnard Society
of Columbia debated the same subject with the Zeloscopic Society of
Pennsylvania. Altogether, next Friday night's debate will be well worth
hearing.
The Hopkins team, which will uphold the affirmative of the question
against Virginia at Chapel Hill the
same night, is composed of Leo
Wolman, G., Ch., and Lindsay Rogers. A. L. Hammond and Abel
Wolman will meet North Carolina
at Charlottesville.

GROTIUS SOCIETY LOSE DEBATE

The Lacrosse Team Covers Itself With
Glory and Mud at Homewood
on Saturday Afternoon.

Arrangements for Contest Are About
Complete and the Event Should
Prove Very Interesting.

Lloyd's Work Exceptional—Lee Makes
Initial Appearance in Mile Run
and Wins—Spring Schedule.

Zelosophic Society of U. of P. Get the
Decision Over Varsity Debaters—A
Supper Tendered Visitors.

The lacrosse team had very little
difficAty in splashing its way to a
victory over Stevens last Saturday.
When the final whistle blew, the
score stood i T to 0, and that with
five men in the line-up who had not
played this season. The field was
soggy and very slippery after two
days' rain, which did not let up
during the game, but their cleated
shoes held the players up well.
At the break, Beatty drove the
ball to Tappan and a rush was made
for the Stevens' goal; but on Bassett
recovering a wild pass, drove the
ball up the field again. Several minutes later Troxell, receiving a pass
from Hulburt, shot for the first
tally. For the rest of the half the
ball was almost always before the
Stevens' net, the mid-fielders following it hard and driving it back as
often as it came up.

Final arrangements for the triangular debate to be held next Friday night between Hopkins, Virginia, and North Carolina, are under
way at all three colleges. Teams
have all been selected and are now
hard at work putting the finishing
touches on their speeches.
The debate in McCoy Hall will
be between Virginia and North
Carolina, Carolina supporting the
negative and Virginia the affirmative
of the question:
"Resolved, That disregarding the
Hav-Pauncefote treaty, the tolls of
the Panama Canal should be the
same for merchant ships of all nations.The Virginia team will consist of
Messrs. Adams and Bozman, speakers. and Via, alternate. North Carolina will be represented by W. F.
Taylor, of the Law School, and
J. C. Busby, of the senior class.

The triangular meet between the
University, the Central Y. M. C. A.,
and the Cross Country Club was
easily taken by the Hopkins team
on Friday. The 220-yard dash was
the only event not won by a 'Varsity
man. Brockman, of the Y. M. C. A.,
won it from Wagner. In eight
events Hopkins won all three places.
It was good to see Lee out again
in the mile run. He won in 4 minutes 443A seconds, remarkable time
for this part of the season and the
water-soaked track. Rain fell all
through the meet. Lloyd won the
Too-yard dash in ToY5 seconds, and
captured the 440 later, in 53/5 seconds, after starting six yards behind
the mark, due to two false starts.
Groover vas close to him at the finish..
The field events were dangerous,
on account of the wet take-off. Dig-

The Grotius Society of Hopkins
was defeated Friday night in their
debate with the Zelosophic Society
of the University of Pennsylvania.
The decision of the judges was two
to one against the Grotius representatives. The orators for the Hopkins' Society were George Rusk,
chairman; David N. Shulman, and
T. J. Tingley. Nachlas was alternate and Gminder advisor. The
Pennsylvanias were: Bell, Pinola,
Brosius, Ripple and Hager. The
subject for debate was compulsory
arbitration for industrial disputes,
the affirmative of which was supported by the Grotius Society.
Before a small but interested audience, Dr. French, who was the
presiding officer, introduced Shulman, Kuehn and Gminder, a trio
that put much life into those present by their rendering of Mozart's
first movement. Tingley was the'

It is needless for us to try to point
out the excellent features of these
plans. The quotations from Dean
Griffin's article are enough, of themselves, to give promise of a happy
life at Homewood. We can only
regret that we, as undergraduates,
will be unable to experience that
life.
Lateness.

Homewood Again.

Some modern sages have remarked that men get more enjoyment in looking forward to a certain
event or pleasure than they do in
the experiencing of the event or
pleasure itself. Whether this is true
or not, we who are to be denied the
enjoyment of the life at Homewood
may yet derive some small amount
of pleasure from looking forward
to the time when the University will
change its quarters, and in talking
of the many fine things that it is
going to- have when it gets there.
One of the advantages that we may
hope to secure when Homewood becomes a reality is the greater facility
afforded for social life among the
students themselves. When the
Johns Hopkins will have its campus
and quadrangle, its dormitories and
frat houses, all grouped together
at. Homewood in "the delightful seclusion of this historic estate, with
its 120 acres of lawn and shade,"
the undergraduate life ought to become broader and mean more to the
student than it can now amid -the
prosaic sights and the disturbing
sounds of city streets." It should,
therefore, be of interest to us all to
learn of the plans that are being
made, for the social side of college
life at Homewood.
In the March issue of the Alumni
Magazine appears an article on "The
College in the University" by Dean
E. H. Griffin, of the college faculty.
Plans for residence at Homewood
are there outlined. The halls Of
residence that may be erected at
Homewood will not be like the traditional college dormitory, with "its
commonplace architecture and the
rough and ready manner of its occupants." Our halls are to be "dignified additions to the group of collegiate buildings, and those who occupy them will observe the same
rules of decorum that would be ob-

"For verily, I say unto you, the
first shall be last, and the last shall
be first."
If we were sure that this were
the motto of many of the undergraduate students in the University,
we would be tempted to believe that
a part, yea, a very large part, of the
students were out trying for the
Rhodes scholarships, Phi Beta
Kappa keys, prizes, honors, etc.
But since our common sense tells
us that no very large part of the
students are trying to become shining stars in the scholarship world,
we must seek some other explanation of the state of affairs that has
led us to believe that perhaps some
of the students had selected the
above quotation as their motto.
The reason why we are brought
to this conclusion must be of itself
apparent to all who attend undergraduate classes. There is hardly
a class from Monday morning until
Friday afternoon where every one
is in his seat, or even in the room,
when the hour bell rings. When
we try to explain this deplorable
condition, we are at a loss to find
adequate -quid propter" s. Of course
when we go to the theatre or to
the cotillon or to a reception, etc.,
it is understood that it would be
highly improper for us to be on
time. But why should this custom
be brought into class? When you
come tripping in, five, ten, or fifteen
minutes after the hour, no one is
benefited by the fact, every one is
disturbed, and you have lost part of.
the lecture or recitation. And the
worst thing about this custom of
being late is the fact that it is largely
due to carelessness and indifference.
You must finish your cigarette.
stump, get the mail from your box,
finish your conversation, tell another
stale joke, or wait for the next uncertain trip of the elevator.

APRIL 14, 1913.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—At the Cotillon Board,
which has undoubtedly been alive
and has improved the cotillons remarkably this year, it may seem ungrateful to throw stones. Before
"casting the first stone," let me mention what the Board has done toward improving the dances: First,
there is a regular receiving committee. As is very proper, all the girls
and men before entering the roOm
are introduced to several of the
chaperons who are on the committee. Much better and more dignified, is it not, than the former practice of never speaking to the chaperons? Second, the music has been
notably bettered. While it seemed
a shame to get rid of the old man
who has played so long and so faithfully at the University functions,
we cannot always sacrifice ourselves
to sentiment. With "Lewie" Fisher
or one of his right hand men,
"ginger" has come into the dances
in a truly remarkable way. Third,
the number of men coming to the
dance has been greatly increased.
The cotillon is now truly a Univer-

sity affair. And if the members of
the Board were present at this writing they could undoubtedly suggest
a fourth or fifth improvement which
has been made, but were I to mention them here I should have no
room to "sling my stones."
Stone No. L—Although the orchestra had finished the first eight
dances by ten or quarter past, the
second half of the dances did not
commence until eleven o'clock. Why
on Saturday night, when we can
only dance until twelve, this lengthy
hour for refreshments. The writer
does not complain. For him the
time passed only too rapidly. He
is slinging in behalf of the stags and
the men who "didn't bring fairies."
The cause for this long intermission
has been given as the poor arrangements for supper. If so, let the arrangements be bettered.
Stone No. 2—Perhaps it was because the noted "Lewie" was performing at the Country Club, and a
substitute was on the job, that one
had to clap like the deuce before getting an encore. And perhaps the
fact that the substitute tired easily
was the reason for the long waits
between dances. To some these
long intermissions might not have
been disagreeable maybe the other
fellows liked to talk more ,than
dance—in striking juxtaposition to
myself.

Scientific Association.

The Johns Hopkins Scientific Association met last Tuesday, April 8,
in the physical laboratory. The meeting was addressed by Mr. John A.
Brashear, on the subject of "Recent
Studies in the Domain of Astrophysics." Mr. Bra.shear has done
much work lately in connection with
the physics of the heavenly bodies,
and his lecture dealt with the results
of his experiments. On Thursday,
April 3, the Association held a subscription dinner in the Johns Hopkins Club. The dinner was followed by a talk on "Recent Work
With Regard to the Constitution of
Matt," by Prof. J. S. Ames. This
lecture was in the nature of a resume of those Professor Ames delivered on his recent trip to the
Northwestern University.

Hopkins and Navy, Evenly Matched,
Put Up a Great Struggle for
Supremacy at Annapolis.

At Annapolis last Thursday 'afternoon, after 65 minutes of the most
Stubborn fighting, the lacrosse game
with the Navy ended with the score
a tie-4 to 4. The two teams could
not have been more evenly matched,
and at no time during the game was
either the Black and Blue or the
Blue and Gold more than one point
ahead.
The rival captains agreed upon
25 and 20 minutes as the time of
the halves, but at the close of these
periods the score stood a tie at 3
to 3. Then it was agreed to play
an extra period of m minutes.
Mainly through the splendid work
of the two goal tenders, neither
team was able to score during this
time. Then a second period of the
same length was agreed upon, at
the end. of which, whatever the
score, the game was to stop. During this time both teams tallied once.
Hopkins drew first blood, when
after about three minutes of play,
Captain Johnny Huck made one of
his famous drives. The advantage
did not last long, however, for,
within a few moments Gray slipped
the ball passed Sears for the Navy's
first count. After twelve more minutes of splendid playing on the part
of both teams, Tappan scored the
second point for the Black and Blue.
Again Navy evened up, Gray caging
the ball for his second goal, and the
half ended with the score 2 to 2.
The Middies began the second
period at a fast clip, and in less than
two minutes Davis succeeded in getting a hard drive into the net. It
was not long, however, before Hollyday succeeded in making a shot
from a mix-up in front of the Navy
goal. There was no more scoring
during this half.
During the first of the extra periods each side had several chances
to score, but both .showed stalwart
defense. After about seven minutes
of the second extra stanza, Navy
gained the lead when Mitchell made
a count. With only three minutes
remaining, Hopkins, showing brilliant ability to come back, took a
wonderful brace, and immediately
evened up the score. The tally was
made by LaMotte, who received a
pass from behind the Middies' goal.
The balance of the time was full
of spirited playing, although both
teams showed the result-of the fast
pace.
Aside from the splendid work of
the two goal tenders, which was
easily the featuresof the game, Huck,
Hollyday, Tappan, and the close attack starred for Hopkins, while
Mitchell, Starkey, Gray and. Davis
played brilliantly for the Navy.

Dr. Paul Eugene Bleuler, professor of psychiatry in the University
of Zurich, Switzerland, who is to
be one of the distinguished guests
at the opening of the new Phipps
Clinic, has already reached Baltimore. He arrived in the city last
Wednesday and will be entertained
during his stay by Dr. Adolf
Meyer, professor of psychiatry in
the Medical School, at his home,
1012 North Calvert street.
Dr. Meyer received a degree of
doctor of laws from the University
of Zurich in 1892.
Sir William Osler, hohorary professor of medicine, now regius professor of medicine at Oxford, will
arrive here on April 15.
The opening of the Phipps Clinic
will take place on April 16, and the
exercises will continue during the
17th and 18th, an elaborate program having been arranged.
The formal opening has been set
for 3 P. M. on the 16th, on which
occasion addresses will be'made by
Dr. Welch, Dr. Stewart Paton,
Judge Harlan and Sir William

Harvard Game on Tuesday.

The baseball game between Harvard and Johns Hopkins which was
to have been the feature of last Saturday's doubleheader, and which
could not be played on account of
rain, will be played tomorrow afternoon at Homewood. The arrangement in regard to the .game for
Tuesday was reached by Manager
F. W. Hubbell of Harvatd and
Manager C. Leland .Getz of the
Johns Hopkins team last Saturday
night. Both teams are very anxious
for the game to be played. If the
weather is good a very large crowd
should turn out for the game, as
Harvard always proves a big drawing card in Baltimore.
Although prevented by the rainy
weather of the past few days from
having a practice since the Princeton game, the Black and Blue nine
is in very good shape. Steady progress has been made since the opening of the season, and the good
showing made against Princeton
last Wednesday is an evidence of
what the Hopkins team is capable
of. With Sutton and Porter back
in the line-up the prospects of
defeating Harvard are especially
bright. All those who are contemplating being present may look forward to a mighty good exhibition of
college baseball. The gam" is
scheduled to start at four o'clock.

HOPKINS WINS PACTICE MEET

The debate should be most interesting for two reasons: First, the
ancient rivalry of . Virginia and
Carolina in the debating field, and
second, the importance of the subject which will be discussed.
Virginia and Carolina have met
four times in debates and each has
the honor of two victories. Each
will, therefore, be fighting for the
"rubber" next Friday night, and
what this means will be realized
when it is considered that out of
thirty-four intercollegiate debates
since 1897, North Carolina has won
twenty-four, and that she considers
Virginia her most important rival.
The Panama tolls seem to be the
most popular debating subject of
the season. They were the subject
of the Harvard-Yale-Princeton triangular debate on March 14. Several weeks later the Barnard Society
of Columbia debated the same subject with the Zeloscopic Society of
Pennsylvania. Altogether, next Friday night's debate will be well worth
hearing.
The Hopkins team, which will uphold the affirmative of the question
against Virginia at Chapel Hill the
same night, is composed of Leo
Wolman, G., Ch., and Lindsay Rogers. A. L. Hammond and Abel
Wolman will meet North Carolina
at Charlottesville.
